scenes.location: OLD TOWN MIDWESTERN SUBURBAN STREET ICY WINTRY
characters: ON THE CLEAR BLUE SKY AS
THEIR VIEW OF THE SCENE IN THE GULCH BELOW
HOLDING ON DON'S RECEDING FIGURE, AS
MRS. OAKLEY IS AT THE PIANO, AND ONE, AND TWO
BACK ON THE OTHERS AT THE TOP OF THE CLIFF
DAD AND SID ARRIVE INTO FRAME.
OVERVIEW FROM A HIGH TOR OVERLOOKING JUNIPER STREET AND
OUR VIEW BEGINS TO PULL BACK
ON THE WOMAN, MRS. OAKLEY, THE DIRECTOR
PULLING BACK, BACK, BACK TO REVEAL
ON RICHIE AT THE TOP OF THE CLIFF
STILL ON JAN LOOKING OUT THE WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: Dad has moved quickly from the house, through the gate, w Mom is just emerging, looking this way, then that way, wh she spots him and calls after him. Dad pays no attention as he heads one way, looks around w a puzzled and then a resolved look on his face, scurries the next direction, and across the street, Max at his sid with Mom yelling after him to stop. He and Max get to the other side of the street, when -- WE HEAR, BUT HE DOESN'T -- SCREECHING BRAKES. The BIG CITY BUS glides on the icy street, trying to stop the driver's face looming large through the window, as he frantically turns the steering wheel... too late.

dialogues.speaker: ON MOM --
dialogues.text: KA-BASH! -- as she's smashed and thrown aside by the bus  like a rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD
dialogues.text: -- as he (and Max) determinedly pushes his way along the  street, unaware of what has happened in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) ...waiting... too late... today, NOT  tomorrow. No wait. The man won't  wait. No wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes, the SCENE BEHIND HIM recedes into the backgro the ruckus. The bus, the crowd, Mom's lifeless body spraw on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about my own life.  It was a piece of crap, and getting  worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUSY EXECUTIVE sits behind her desk, trying to listen carefully. DON, early 40's, dressed in his best suit, has his laptop computer set up on her desk, and he pushes buttons from o read-out to the next, a graphic journey through life's  actuarial statistics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...at age sixty, you'll have what  you need to retire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but not what I WANT to retire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good point. So, how much is  that? Supposing you want half a  million in securities, plus an income  of $65,000 a year, you'll have to  add to your IRA...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um-hmmm-hah!!? I'll need ten million  in the bank, and one million a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That much? No one needs a million a  year. You have to be realistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do YOU know that I am  not being realistic. I'm a fucking  money machine. There's a pot of gold  on the other side of Mount Hood just  waiting for me! I, Mr. SalesMan have,  vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flexes her bicep and her bosom simultaneously. Don no getting the point. The intercom buzzes. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your office... for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don gets up to take the phone, knocks his laptop into a v tries to catch it, but too late... the vase crashes into dozen pieces on the hard floor. He grimaces, she rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean? I was dead meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Don, squeezed in the middle seat, sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadn't been home in five years.  Duluth, Minnesota... the kind of  town people are from but never go  to. When I called, -- once a week,  every Sunday, when I had Richie with  me... those Sundays when I had paid  Susie her monthly pound of flesh...  the ransom... for letting me see my  own son... I'd talk to my Mom, but  she'd say Dad was in the basement  working on his wooden toys. He sold  his hardware store and retired just  so he could do that, it turned out  to be a pretty good business, little  toy stores all over the country bought  his old fashioned wooden toys --  then at Christmas, he'd send one to  Richie and one to my sister's kids...  and he'd always keep a few to give  'em away whenever he met a kid.  Anyway, when Mom said he was busy in  the basement, I always figured that  he just didn't want to talk to me...  sure he taught me to play hockey,  but he also beat the crap out of me  when I was thirteen, and to this  day, I never knew why... what had I  done? So it just seemed better if he  pretended to be working on his toys  when I called. I think we spend our  whole lives trying to please our  fathers, but I was beginning to  believe... you can't. And now, I  guess it was too late. Oh, well, oh,  shit, now Mom's dead, Dad's got...  what did they call it, Old Timer's  disease... Oh, well, oh, shit, life  is a bitch, and then you die. Ho.  Ho. Ho. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don turns over in his sleep as best he can in the cramped economy class seat in the middle. As he turns over, he pu on the seat in front of him with one hand, and elbows som extra room from the heavyset lady next to him. Eyes burn him from two directions but Don doesn't notice it. ON HIS LAPTOP COMPUTER SCREEN: Actuarial tables and  statistics.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: His eyes pop open, staring, sad.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD
dialogues.text: Mumbling to himself, sweating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? Is that you? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SCENE REVEALED)

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Dad's knees dug into the snow, as he searches through the snow, pulling out dormant tulip bulbs as he finds them. M thinks it's a game, barks, grabs for the tulips, doesn't  like 'em, barks again. A "companion", a fat black woman,  stands in the doorway of the house. Don is well behind Dad, suitcase in hand, speaking to him but not heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Hurry... hurry... nothing there.  Nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Don drops to his knees next to Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad turns, looks at him, blinks, hands Don some tulips, a keeps digging through the snow. Don is bewildered, puzzled, sad, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time. No time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, Max, Don. In the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is on the phone. The Black Woman is bundled up waitin by the phone. Dad is sitting in his usual chair, staring  ahead, planning his next devilish move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't be in two places at once,  Mel. No. No. Of course I want my  son... to live with me... he's been  with his... can't you get a  continuance or whatever... it's today,  the funeral's today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel Chase, an overworked patrician, stands behind his des in Portland, Ore., signing documents for his secretary wh Don's disembodied voice crackles on a speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...my mother's funeral, Mel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, Don... so then just  drag yourself on a plane... and get  back to Portland... if you want your  kid to live with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING -- IN THE KITCHEN, Dad has that gleam in his eye. The black teenager moves to Don, looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I've got my Dad now... can't  the judge... just...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge can excuse a funeral...  but that's it... do what you have to  do, and get back or lose the deal,  that's the deal. Your "ex" is already  here in town, her lawyer is champing  at the bit and the hearing is day  after tomorrow, 1 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will this cover it? Overnight, plus  today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the black teenager some money. She shrugs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the overhead latch to go out. Swish! Dad darts the door, squeezes in front of the girl... and he's gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God! (on phone) Later!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don drops the phone, and runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Max moving fast, across the yard, through the fen and just about to cross the icy street, as Don catches up grabs Dad by the arm. Dad flails his arm free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You! You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad pokes his finger into Don's chest a half dozen times. Don just takes it, as --

dialogues.speaker: OUR VIEW
dialogues.text: revealing the icy streets of the small town, -- tableau's changing America-people jogging, their breaths steaming i the cold air, shoveling snow on driveways and paths,  "hometown" is in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no, no! That way. Don't you know...  anything!? That way... no. no. no.  Not ping. Nose. Nose! Can't you see...  the man... the man... he's waiting...  you me late. Making.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD AND DON
dialogues.text: -- in the back seat of a limousine, dressed in dark suits and coats. Dad is agitated, wide-eyed, gesturing wildly, this way an that. Don is trying to maintain his cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you... this way... it's THAT  way. Turn that way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... he can't turn that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't you know... the man...  that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this man? Just say his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name? You mean your wife. My  mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes glaze over. Beat. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... don't you remember? She died.  We're going to her funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad cocks his head like a puzzled puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? (a beat, he thinks) Will she be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dad, she'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright day, the sun glistening on the snowy ground, as caravan of just five or six cars led by the hearse and th family limousine pull slowly around the rolling grounds. Some of the signs of the solemn side of Christmas in the  cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: THE BURIAL SITE
dialogues.text: The gravediggers help to unload the casket from the hears as the mourners take their places.

dialogues.speaker: GREEK ORTHODOX PRIEST
dialogues.text: In Greek or Latin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the Markopoulis family and its  friends, we gather in sorrow and to  celebrate God's eternal way, to lay  Gladys Spyros Markopoulis to her  eternal rest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest continues on as -- IN THE BACKGROUND, a taxicab pulls up, and a woman gets o and hurries to join the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My older sister, Cicely, the righteous  bitch was always fashionably late,  even to her mother's funeral. It's  her Godgiven right to do as she  pleases without caring about anyone  else. She's perfect, and the rest of  us are only there as flaws to allow  her perfection to be seen by  comparison. Luckily for her, she  married a husband who can pay for  the luxury of her perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cicely arrives at the group, stands next to Don. Whispers harshly for all to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you wait? Funerals don't  have to start on time. You could  have had them wait. My plane circled  the city for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving Cicely the satisfaction of an  answer could result in a ten minute  monologue on why I'm no good, and  she's the only one on earth worth  shit. That's why I limited my answer  to one word. "Oh."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the best you can say? "Oh."  It's my mother's funeral, and all  you can say is "oh." Well, of course,  since you're the one who killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. I thought she was killed by  a Pontiac station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Jokes. At your mother's funeral.  Where's Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest had been droning on, and only WE HAVE NOTICED  that DAD drifted away from the whispering siblings... and now, when they both look around... he's gone. The two siblings each scan, turning their heads in opposi directions and around their respective bodies, until thei heads meet on the backside with their eyes locked on the  same view.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR VIEW
dialogues.text: Dad, in the distance, just disappearing into the oldest p of the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking for the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man? This is no time to look  for some man. It's his wife's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hurry up... how could you let  him do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don slips away from the group, but not without notice, as one, then all eyes, turn to his receding figure, as the P goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was beginning to enjoy the sheer  madness of it all. My Dad was no  crazier than my sister, at least he  had an excuse. I was starting to  feel a connection with him --  something that I hadn't felt in a  long time. It wasn't something I  could put my finger on, not yet. All  I knew for openers was that I wanted  to help him find the man. My Dad was  already in his second childhood, and  you know what, I was jealous. I wanted  to be in my second childhood too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON disappears through the same place in the cemetery's o section, where the tombstones are high and the uncaretake growth around them is even higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don makes his way through the aisles of gravestones and  growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don goes through the crowded area, passing by tombstones, which we read as he goes by. These are the stones of the  long departed, some going back to the turn of the century and before that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, where are you? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves along, past tombstones, calling out for Dad, and then -- -- he trips and falls nearly flat on his face in the snow and from that vantage point, he looks up to see -- Dad! Scurrying through, confused, scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...!! Dad... stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, startled, stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you be?... looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad comes over to him...and helps him get up out of the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU were looking for ME? I was looking  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes right... looking for you. Me  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DON, his head cocked now like a puzzled puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't figure it out, was he the  crazy man, or was I the crazy man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From nowhere, the voice of Cicely is unmistakable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there you are... just like you.  The funeral's not even over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone from the funeral is there, all ten or twelve peo ad-libbing that they hope everything's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, don't worry... it's okay, my  father just wanted to mourn in his  own way, away from... you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of course everyone says they understand except for Ci as Don leads Dad along the way, and the whole crowd passe by the old tombstones, and -- HOLD ON ONE TOMBSTONE as everyone passes by, but does not notice --

dialogues.speaker: IT READS
dialogues.text: Tyrus Markopoulis - Loving Son, Loving Father - 1866-1943 And then, PANNING as people pass by, but do not notice th stone is next to the first one --

dialogues.speaker: SECOND STONE READS
dialogues.text: Boris Markopoulis - Loving son, Loving Father - 1905-1966

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... I admit it. I was stupid.  Dad had been looking for his own  father's grave... and he found it  but didn't see it. And neither did  I. I didn't see it. I just didn't  see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cemetery workers are finishing the job of shoveling t dirt into the grave over the coffin, as the mourners reem from the Old Cemetery section in the deep background, wit the shrillness of Cicely's voice stinging the cold winter air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was going on here? So stupid,  at my mother's funeral. How can anyone  mourn with crazy people all around?  Don, it's really your fault...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the mourners, a man Don's age, approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don... I'm Vic Hudnut... we were in  Miss Troxell's fourth grade class  together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to remember) Oh... yes, hi, Vic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything, anything I can  do... don't hesitate to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic puts a business card into Don's lapel pocket, pats hi on the back for old times sake and he's gone before Don c blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Don... I have to catch the  8:30 flight, and you've just ruined  my Mom's funeral. Here, you take  Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves Dad in to Don, and -- the waiting cab having pu up, opened its door... she's gone. Don's reaction as --

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK, BACK, BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Don and Dad and, of course, Max, standing together, alone and aimless in the vast cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don's face, horizontal, his eyes wide open, staring ahead as morning light streaks across his face, and PULLING BAC He is in his boyhood bedroom, and nothing has really chan Memorabilia of the mid-1980's- Michael J. Fox beams from poster of BACK TO THE FUTURE. Don as a member of the Dulu High School track team. Skis. He's under a bedspread with racing car printed on it. His eyes roam the room and he  finally fixes on a big, no doubt purloined, burlesque  poster... ROSE LA ROSE, the Queen of Texas Burlesque... h grins a little remembering the night he and his friends s off with the giant poster. Suddenly, the door bursts open. It's Dad, stark naked. Max by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. Not in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. Mom died. She's not coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don rises, sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom died, Dad. She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, walks out. Max following. Don watches. The grin he wore for ROSE LA ROSE now replac by a sad grimace. He picks up the card he was given at th funeral, and dials on his old Incredible Hulk dial phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic Hudnut please... oh, Vic, it's  Don Markel... I hope it's not too  early to call... (Suddenly a CRASH is  heard... maybe a pot  or pan) Vic... could you come by my Dad's  house... well, as soon as you can...  I have to get back for a court case  in Portland... tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another CRASH is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... yeah... see you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don dashes out of the room... another crash is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don runs into the kitchen. The toaster is in the sink wit the water running, causing electrical sparks and buzzes, Dad is not there. Another CRASH is heard, more distinctive, garbage cans an hardware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. (his eyes widen) Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crashing sounds, as Don slips and slides, falls, gets up enters through a side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DON -- FROZEN in a stance of sheer terror.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW --
dialogues.text: Dad is in the car, naked, driving back and forth, smashin into the garbage cans and his old work shop machines, woo toys falling off the shelves above, then back into the wo garage door, cracking it. Max, the dog, is in the car too

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... stop! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don tries to open the car door but Dad is locked in, and  doesn't hear him. We can see Dad talking to himself insid and then he sees Don trying to open the door, but pays no attention. He crashes into the garage door, bam, and then crashes again, wildly shifting the gear lever back and fo Finally, Don gloms onto a shovel from nowhere, and with a his might, he hits the back window of the moving car, but doesn't break. He keeps hitting it and hitting it, and do realize that the car has stopped and Dad, naked, has step out of the car, and is watching Don curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't act crazy. Don't act crazy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don does a take, freezes the shovel above his head, and l at Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, Don exchanges a look with his Dad. His Dad ges meaninglessly. Relieved, Don mimics the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don has Dad into his underwear shorts and pants, and is  kneeling to put on socks and shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what Mom did for you everyday?  And she kept it all a secret...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do my own!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad kicks off the shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUST A MINUTE! I'll be there in a  minute!! (struggling with the  shoe) Come on Dad. Let me do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Dad struggle some more, and he finally gets the ot shoe on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now the shirt... and... we'll  get you down for some breakfast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the one?

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: As Vic enters the room, sees the problem, picks up Dad's  shirt and holds it open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Mom's house was always open,  Don... just walk in -- cookies and  hot chocolate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Don directs Dad's arms into the sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you remember things, and I  remember nothing... my Mom had  cookies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left town, Donny, and I stayed.  So, I remember... even if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They direct Dad out of the room. Max follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were a real estate  agent, not a psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freud, that's who got us into all  this hot soup... and Hitler... but I  forgive them both...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. Mom's chair is featured. The gallery wall in the b As Don and Vic lead Dad into the room. Max too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very few historians see the connection  between Freud and Hitler. They were  both just frustrated and angry men...  like everybody else. What's for  breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit Dad down in the chair in front of the gallery of snapshots. The water is still running over the now smokin toaster in the sink. Don turns off the water, wipes off t toaster while Vic forages in the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...guess it won't be toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess not. But, here's some milk  and... cereal... and orange juice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth a shot.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD --
dialogues.text: sitting motionless, expressionless, staring, and then, he starts to blink curiously at his view.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: -- empty.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON SCENE
dialogues.text: As Don puts the glass of juice in front of Dad, and Vic p a bowl of cereal in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Dad... you have to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad stares ahead, blinking. ON MOM'S CHAIR -- empty. PULLING BACK FAST to Dad's hands as he suddenly sweeps ac the table, knocking the juice and the cereal all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dad, come on! Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad jumps up from the table and heads away. Don starts af him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go... he's okay. Here...  check this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don spreads some papers on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The listing. Sign here and the house  will be listed and advertised right  away. We'll price it, say, $15,000  over the market... leave some room  to negotiate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Dad punches the window open, and throws out some feed for the birds on the feeding station. The birds come immediately. Max woofs and growls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic... maybe we could just rent it  out, the house out, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until when, Donny? -- you'll need  the cash to pay the nursing home.  Lots of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don nods, takes the pen and signs. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... let's go see if we can find  the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad turns from the birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is she there now? You know his  bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go ahead... go see the man. I  can clean up around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man... she's there now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dad... he's there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dokeyokey, you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad turns to go, trips over Mom's chair, then straightens the chair back to its exact original position. Max starts follow him. Vic grabs Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I'll put the dog in the  back yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is ready to break into pieces. He nods to Vic, and ta Dad out the door. HOLD on Mom's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have the heart to tell Dad  where he was going. I felt bad about  tricking him... even though he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Dad. Don at the wheel. Dad is seat-belted in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wouldn't know the difference...  or maybe he would. I thought about  how when I was seven years old... He  asked me if I wanted to go to Camp  Cherokee for the summer.

dialogues.speaker: DAD'S VIEW
dialogues.text: Dad is looking around, turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no, no, not the place. Where are  you going... that way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad... let's try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don takes a left hand turn, hometown nostalgia blurs thro the windshield. INTERCUTTING, DON AND DAD with the scenery

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I said no to Camp Cherokee. I  wanted to stay home... I had to stay  home. I had to conquer riding my new  bike, and I told him how important  THAT was to me. So, he said, okay  that we won't go to Camp Cherokee...  we'll just take a ride in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Vic Hudnut says goodbye to Max the dog, shuts the door Max's sad look and gets into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going!! ...not the place!!  That way! You know which way it is!  Why do you do it!!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK ON SCENE -- Dad and Don in the car, driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to find the man for you,  Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don takes another turn... heading in a new direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. Then, suddenly, a window is smashed open and Max j through the flying shards, lands on his feet in the snow, and takes off across the back yard and into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you? Why for you? The man can't  wait... where is the ticket! The  ticket! The ticket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max disappears into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needless to say when we got to Camp  Cherokee, I was beside myself. I  yelled and screamed at my Dad! You  tricked me! You tricked me! And I  swore too. You tricked me... you...  you... COMMUNIST! It was the worst  thing anyone could call anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is getting very frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... don't... not this way! That  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dad, I'm pretty sure. It's this  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You! Never right! Stupid!  Stupid... Turn... turn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad grabs the wheel and he and Don start struggling. Dad  strains to reach over the seat belt straps, and he has an iron grip on the wheel. INTERCUT: On the streets, the car swerves, barely missing another car. A truck honks! The car slides on the ice, bo off a tree and keeps going. INSIDE THE CAR, Don is pulling at Dad's hands, and they a screaming at each other furiously. Don wins the battle, but now Dad keeps flailing at Don's  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good! You're not good! Bad! Bad  boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, as a kid, rowing a boat like a demon in a race on th lake at Camp Cherokee. Cheering spectators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That did hurt. No matter how old we  are, I guess, we still want to show  our Dad that we're a good person...  not a bad person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DON, THE KID'S determined face, teeth gritted...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Don turns up a long graveled driveway towards an old mans Dad notices the long, snowy drive towards the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dad, this is the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad struggles violently to undo his seat belt, but he can figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don almost wins the race. He comes in second. The winner accoladed by the other kids and counselors. Don, the kid, alone in his rowboat, destroyed and alone in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON SCENE
dialogues.text: The car pulls up in front of the mansion where a small si reads: OLD OAKS-RETIREMENT HOME (Mentally challenged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don helps Dad to undo his seat belt, and Dad bolts out of the car... and despite Don's protest... scurries up the s of the portico... as a woman walks out. Don takes a deep breath behind the wheel, watching Dad th the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing... even though I was  really pissed about being tricked, I  really had a great time at Camp  Cherokee that summer. I won a boat  race. But, I never bothered to tell  my Dad. I wanted him to suffer for  his crime.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WOMAN, MRS. OAKLEY, THE DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: as Dad approaches her with purpose in his every step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Metropolis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her greeting is warm, and Dad responds sociably. He smile and takes her offered hand, babbling incoherently as if h known her all his life.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: Don shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's another thing. Dad was always  nicer to complete strangers than he  ever was to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come in, Mr. Metropolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Mark-op-olus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Max appears!... in a great leap over a rocky wa dashes across the snow, joins Dad at his side with Mrs. O as they go in the front door of the Mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Oakley takes Dad by the arm. He feels comfortable with her, as Don catches up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You're also Mr. Metropolis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Don Markel. Mar-kel. My Dad's  last name is Markopoulis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Please hold on to the  dog... many patients are afraid of  dogs. And you understand... of  course...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... um... yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don sees Max, does a take, looks around; takes Max by the collar and tries to keep up. Mrs. Oakley walks them into the Activities Room. Antique and women wandering, sleeping, pretending to listen to th Activities Director reading the newspaper to them. A remarkably spry and zaftig older woman in a sort of rag nurse's outfit approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Old-Timers ward. Your  father has been diagnosed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Cooper. Yes, senile dementia  is Dr. Sidney's diagnosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad. That means he'll be in  my care. Oho... how handsome and not  tooo... old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes Dad's arm and cuddles him close to her substant old bosom. Dad's eyes pop. He likes it. He reaches out fo feel; and she moves her bosom right into his hands. He la on to her bosom for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Cooper, please. Mr. Metropolis  still has to be admitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NURSE Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at his son, Don. Still holding 'Nurse' Cooper's bosom. His eyes steely and far off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is taken aback. So sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... I want to see your room...  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don's eyes start to cloud. He moves to kiss his Dad. Dad  holds on to one bosom while he flails his other arm viole pushing Don away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told... GOOD-BYE. You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is hurt like a little boy, his eyes beginning to tear Dad flails his arms violently again and again, he pushes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. Why are you so angry with me?  What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this is the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Dad gives Don a mighty shove with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... please... I need to know...  why did you beat me up... when I was  thirteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Dad rushes Don full force, flailing at him mercilessl while Don uses his arms to cover himself without hurting father. Max is barking. Mrs. Oakley is yelling. Don is be pummeled mercilessly, when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beat you up? I don't remember  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Vic Hudnut. As usual, he's appeared from nowhere. Da stops the pummeling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought something for Dad's room.  I hope it's okay. He loves birds...  and I know they don't allow dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic produces a birdcage with two parakeets, on a stand. DAD grabs the birdcage and stand, and heads up the hallwa with Nurse Cooper on one arm, and Mrs. Oakley on the othe Max starts to follow, but Vic catches him by the collar. whines.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON --
dialogues.text: breathless and shaken. Max's whining is HEARD OVER, allow US the impression that it could be Don who is whining.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON'S VIEW
dialogues.text: ...Dad disappearing down the hall and through a set of do doors.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: The "redeye", most people are sleeping in semi-darkeness, but Don's face is spotlighted by the reading light above. stares ahead, his laptop computer on a musical notes scre saver, waiting for his command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't figure anything out. I  never did know why my Dad had beat  me up when I was thirteen and now he  tried it again. My son, Richie was  now thirteen and scheduled to tell  the judge whether he wanted to live  with his Mom, who was moving to  Hawaii, or with me who he had only  seen on some weekends and holidays  for the last three years. And  Christmas was only two days away.  Then, it struck me that I hadn't had  a moment to grieve the loss of my  mother, and I wondered why I hadn't  even shed a tear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the computer, little dancing musical notes. Just a gli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'Old Timers' patients are at dinner, in various state of dress, some are in hospital robes, but most are dresse It is a study in slow eating. They are having soup, and e eats his or her own soup in his own way... just watching soup, lifting a spoon in an agonizingly slow process to t lips, and one man, the man next to Dad is slurping his so very quickly. He might be ninety, skinny as a rail. Dad i not eating his soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pissed, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...day but not too much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was pissed my first few days too...  but you gotta eat... and the food's  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sid Graybar. Remember Graybar  Heating... delivered coal... all  over town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good day. You had a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best in town. How's your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid laughs loudly, upsetting some ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet. You idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat your soup, you old bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gasps. Dad laughs. Sid nods knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be okay. We can be buddies...  or didn't you notice... we're the  only two men here... these damn wimmin  outlive their husbands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... too bad is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper gets up, comes around the table to Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, listen, Mr. Metropolis. You  listen to me... it's almost bedtime,  and I have a little extra time to  tuck you in early. Would you like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks up at her, blinking. She takes his hand and  practically lifts him out of his chair. The other women shake their heads and ad-lib their  disapproval. Sid can only grin wickedly. In the background, a few patients are putting gifts under the Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks off the plane amongst people being greeted all  around him, but he walks through alone. The Portland airport is adorned with Martha Stewart K-Mar Christmas decorations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic said Max would just keep escaping  to run to Dad at the Nursing home,  so it would be best if I gave Max  away to someone in Portland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hi Mr. Dog... did you have a  good trip? Waiting for your master?

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: A funky, spunky young woman dressed like Annie Hall would she worked on a farm. She sweet talks Max, as --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: Don has picked up his bag from the carousel and is walkin over to Max's cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so cute? What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has an old spirit. My daughter  would love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... he's looking for a good home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is?... You've got to be joking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max had done it again. He found  himself a new home and introduced me  to the love of my life. Jan. Of  course, I didn't know that 'til later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is lying on his stomach in his bed. His shirt is off "Nurse" Cooper is now pulling off his pajama pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, this is very good. Mr.  Metropolis. I need to examine you  completely, and then I'm going to  give you a full body sponge bath.  Are you comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the tic-up rub the milk. Petes  sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you like it when I examine  the back of your thigh...? Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good... good. My money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid Graybar ambles into the room, pays little attention t what Nurse Cooper is doing, and she pays little attention him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is your room? It's just  like my room... Oh, this IS my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid recalls that the lone Christmas card on his bedside t is his, but he puzzles over just who "YOUR BISMARK INSURA AGENT" might be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving him a full body  examination, but I can't give you  one. Doctor's orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has gone a little beyond the thigh. Dad's head pops u in a state of wide-eyed ecstatic surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But see my side of the room. I have  pictures of my wife and my sister,  but you don't have any pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse turns Dad over on his back. Now, her eyes pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh. OoooOh. Look out. That's good,  honey, That's very good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly she throws a towel over his mid-section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you have family still living.  You have two birds. But not me, I'm  86 and I've outlived everybody I  ever knew. (Sid leans over  parallel to Dad's  face and into his  eyes) Nurse doing a good job on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know I'm here with the nuts  in the Looney bin because I want to  be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yow-wa-eeee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid climbs into his own bed, just a few feet from Dad's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody brought me here. I brought  myself because I didn't want to live  alone. They didn't have a room for  me in the Cody Wing... so they put  me in here. I could've moved, but I  like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real nurse, Mrs. Russel, comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody tucked in. You need some  help Mr. Metropolis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad gasps incoherently. Suspicious, Mrs. Russell enters  towards Dad. "Nurse" Cooper ducks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's...? Oh, dear, Miss Cooper...  This isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She huffs past Mrs. Russel, with one last word at the doo as she escapes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He only needs love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Russel gives a last bedcheck to both Dad and Sid. Sh puts a cover over Dad's naked body, tucks him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... tomorrow's another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes, leaving FULL ROOM SHOT OF dad and Sid in the se darkness lying in their beds. Sid looks at the ceiling as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too bad you didn't meet Herb.  Well... of course, you couldn't meet  Herb because he died last week...  then of course if he hadn't died,  you wouldn't be my new roommate  because you're sleeping in Herb's  old bed. But you woulda liked Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bat for sincey... how date pile,  ticket for the man... then man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking for the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the company... guess the birds...  to go but boxes lost to wooden... go  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING IN on the parakeets in their cage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... but you can't worry about it  now. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dokeyokey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two parakeets are already sleeping. FADE OUT on the two parakeets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so each parent wants you to live  with them... go to school. You've  lived with your Mom for the last  four years... why shouldn't you  continue to live with her now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RICHIE -- Thirteen, bright, non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...she's moving to Hawaii, but I  want to play Hockey. They don't have  hockey there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER -- Hearing room includes Don and his lawyer, Mel, a Susie, Don's ex, and her lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want to live with your Dad,  here in Portland, where they do have  hockey? And some good schools, I  might add.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe, but my Dad has to work  every day and he lives in a little  condo, but my Mom is rich... or her  new fianc? is rich... and they are  moving into a big house... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you'd be better off there...  she'll take you to school every day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Well, she sleeps 'till eleven  every morning, so, she can't take  me... but I could take a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, there's no hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge turns to the parents and lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, which of you two really wants  this boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both parents and both lawyers answer simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. She does, your honor, he does,  I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge looks at all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear of the wisdom of  Solomon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invoking the wisdom of Solomon...  and knowing that Richie here can  stay through New Year's to see how  he likes living with his Dad... (Susie gasps!) For a change. He's been living with  you for four years... and I really  think the only person here capable  of deciding who Richie should live  with is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all hang on his final word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sly and knowing grin, he brings the gavel down! They are all severally and individually dumbfounded, mout agape. Even Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's small, but it has a great view of the city lights of Portland, Ore. Good guess he's on the 20th floor of a dow high-rise condo building. Chic, but clinical. A tiny, pla tabletop Christmas tree with a few gifts is a sad looking concession to the holiday spirit. Don is couch-potatoing, doing three things at once, watch the Blazers on TV, working some actuarial figures on his  laptop computer, and talking to Max, who lies on the floo watching him for his next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Blazers) ...good God, put the damn ball in  the basket!! Oh, no... Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's half-time. Blazers lead by a point. He shakes his he starts typing, but Max is eyeballing him, and he feels it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Max... don't look at me like  that. I didn't create the situation.  I just play the hand I'm dealt...  and if I can play the hand I'm dealt  so can you... 'cause you're a dog.  Just a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. His cell phone rings, too. He walks with the cell phone to the door, looks through t peephole. Opens the door. The young woman in jeans and a  funny hat is there, this time with little girl in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... Mr. Markel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... oh, you're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan Patrick. My daughter, Bren. To  meet Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone buzzes insistently. He finally answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... you want to meet Max. (on phone) Don Markel. Oh... um... hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it okay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Max! Come here, Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks over the couch with a curious look on his wise face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Bren, isn't he great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bren this is Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. They both pet Max, who is friendly but cautio Don moves away into the kitchen area, with his back to th While Bren and Jan check out Max in the foreground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On phone) Susie? Sorry... um... okay, so how  do you want to arrange this... fine,  he can stay with you tonite in the  hotel, and I'll pick him up  tomorrow... Yes, I've already got  him the hockey stuff. Yes, I can  afford it. Yes, I can afford the  time... I'll make the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns to the living area... carrying a leash and a d dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jan and Bren) You like Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we need a big dog to protect the  chickens from the mountain lions.  Bren? You like Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him. Mom...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, yes... Mr. Markel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain lions... Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry he's big... so they won't  even try to fight him. Unless they're  really hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don's not sure, but nods anyway, and hands over the leash and the dog dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also have a cat... and Max will  love Greta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cat named Greta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't keep a dog. It's a no  pets building. (into the phone) Hold on, Susie... hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. So, um, Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don blinks. Oh, yeah, Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas. Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yes... Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don gives Max a farewell pat on the head and ushers them  out. Watches them go down the hall. Max turns his head ba to look at Don, then continues down the hall with his new owners. Way down the hall, at the elevator, Bren hugs Max, then h her Mom. Don remains in the foreground on cordless phone hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mom, he's great. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie... okay, so, it's O.K. I'll  pick him up. Send his P.J's... ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Have a good trip.  Merry Christmas Aloha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug again and board the elevator. Don hangs up the phone. FOLLOW DON back into his condo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha. Ho. Ho. Ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plops back down on the couch. Scottie Pippen blocks a  shot. He looks at the TV with a glassy eyed stare. Sighs. Suddenly, with one sweeping, seething, flail of his arms, like Dad, Don knocks everything off the coffee table,  including the sad little Christmas tree and gifts... and  seethes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! What kind of a life is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: Rasheed Wallace swoops through the air, and slam d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TWO BIRDS... chirping at the DAWN. Dad is staring at the ceiling, wide-eyed, in the same pos as he went to bed. Sid is fast asleep. Dad hears the birds chirping. He gets out of bed, looks a the birds, throws some seed on their little feeding stati They eat, chirp, he grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad grins, and responds... to the birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Chr... Chri...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice belongs to a new nurse, a male nurse, Derrick, big black guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am, Mr. Macropoulis (Dad whirls around) Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at him like he's crazy. Derrick picks up the ph at bedside, holds the receiver in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your son. In Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad blinks. Puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, your son, Don, in Oregon. He  wants to wish you a Merry Christmas. (Dad just blinks) On the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad just blinks. Sid sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your son. On the telephone.  Your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at Sid, looks at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... doo, your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad takes the phone to his ear, but he's got it upside do We can hear Don trying to talk through the phone. "Dad, a you there...?" Dad blinks, knocks the receiver a couple o times on the edge of the bedside table to make it work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, try it this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derrick takes the receiver and turns it around correctly Dad's ear. We can hear Don's Voice trying to make contact

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad can hear Don but he just blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Hello, Mister Macropoulis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad just blinks, not sure what to do. Sid rises up again, looks at Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Hello to your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad brightens, seems to understand Sid. What is it about  Sid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Hel-lo...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derrick gives the high sign to Sid.

dialogues.speaker: DAD'S ROOM ON PHONES
dialogues.text: Don is on the phone while in the background Richie is put on an array of hockey equipment... just out of the boxes. Don has a cheap electronic keyboard that Richie gave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... how are you doing there? Are  they taking care of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's frustrating. Dad's voice is all mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called to wish you a Merry  Christmas. Merry Christmas. (Dad's voice-incoherent) I said... MERRY CHRISTMAS!! (..."who?") I'm with Richie on Christmas Day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bitchy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie! My son. Your grandson. He  wants to talk to you. (to Richie) Richie... it's Grampa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don brings the phone to Richie's ear. Richie takes the ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Grampa. (Dad mumbles) Huh? What did you say? (Dad mumbles) I can't understand what you are  saying. Are you okay? How is Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sex. Yes... play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dog, Max. How is Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DON, biting his lip, eager to take the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No attacks. (to Sid) She can't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. This is Sid Graybar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? ...oh, it's for you. Sid Graybar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your Dad's roommate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, how's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and I are buddies. He's doing  fine. He wants me to tell you and  your boy... Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dad is already wandering out of the room, having trou with the doorknob. Finally, he gets it and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Richie, walking along the riverside park near the great fountain. Richie is definitely overdressed in the p and uniform of a big time hockey player, the white goalie mask is worn by Don flipped up on his forehead, and he al carries Richie's hockey stick and Richie's skates are car over Don's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but why didn't anyone tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did tell you, Rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean then... WHEN she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you were at your Mom's, and I  think she probably felt it would be  better if I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never going to see my grandma  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. Don has his own feelings about his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I see Grampa again, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth? (Richie looks at him.  ...the truth, of  course) I don't know. In any case, you can  tell, Grampa will never be the same  person you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can tell. But, you know  something, Dad. Grampa knows about  life... and I'll bet he still knows  how to have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead of them is the ice-rink... and also, some people  walking... a dog. Don stops, does a take. Squints. Yep, it's the young woman, Jan Patrick, and her daughter another kid, walking a dog, and yep, the dog is Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Grampa's dog... did they  allow Max at the old folks home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un... no... um... I mean yes, yes  they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did! That's really neat... Grampa  loves that dog. They're... like,  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman and kids and Max go into the enclosure of the  outdoor skating rink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Richie... it's getting awfully  cold, and... um... I forgot to tell  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...forgot what...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...um... to tell you... I'm not really  feeling that well, and... um... we  have that party to go to... we'll  just have to do hockey... um...  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dad, I'm taking a lesson. Mr.  Bolton is waiting... That party is  tonite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and the woman and kids are getting closer. Don physic turns Richie around and heads the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, I'm getting really sick... I  have to go back to the condo... I'm  really sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think you're having your  period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don gives him a funny look, and pushes him along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd lied to my son, and... don't  think I didn't feel bad about it.  But why? Richie could handle the  truth. Hah! O.K. I got it. I'm the  one... who couldn't handle the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ON JAN PATRICK --
dialogues.text: with Bren and Max, the dog, and a couple of other kids, h eye caught something at a distance... Don having turned a walked the other way with Richie... she stops, wonders, t joins the others again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost all the patients are just sitting and sleeping in  chairs. A big Christmas tree dominates the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, everybody. Perk up...  we're going to light the Christmas  tree... and it's almost 2 o'clock...  visitors and singing... and gifts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the switch to light the big tree, which is beaut Most everyone looks spacey-eyed at the tree, and one woma applauds a little. Sid and Dad sit together amongst fifteen women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nothing. I've seen better.  That's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad nods his agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have some real fun if they'd  let us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something naughty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad nods. Sid looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sticks her nose up indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gotten your share of sponge  baths from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-ho-ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at Dad. Sid and Nurse do a take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-ho-ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-ho-ho... Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several middle-aged people and a few kids are trooped in  through the main hallway into the living room, bearing  Christmas gifts... They spread out to their mothers and  grandmothers, "Merry-Christmas" ing as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-ho-ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse and Dad giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and Don are trekking in the rain with an umbrella, gifts in hand towards the house. So is another father and his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it, Dad. If you don't  know anybody... who do you give the  gifts to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just put 'em under the tree. I  give mine to any Mom, and you give  yours to any other kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't even know 'em? How do  you know these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it in the newspaper. It's for  single parents and their kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ring the doorbell. Someone answers immediately. And  overweight earth mother with a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... I'm Nan. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs Don and then hugs Richie. They look at each othe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in... put your gifts under  the tree. Betty, Peter... this is...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Don... this is Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... Merry Christmas !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Peter take turns hugging Don and Richie, who se each other over the shoulders of the huggers and exchange wide-eyed pleas of helplessness. They stop hugging and three more people line up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start to hug Don and Richie, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, old patients, dressed up on their 40's and 50's their children, nurses, Mrs. Oakley, gifts have been  exchanged. The patients try on their new sweaters and war booties. Some have been given toys, rubber balls to squee a slinky, and -- Mrs. Oakley is at the piano, leafing through a book of  Christmas Carols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I got a tie. My nephew in  North Dakota. He's seventy-two...  and you thought I didn't have any  living relatives. I think I gave HIM  this tie... fifteen years ago. What'd  you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More... today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad opens a little jewel box, and pulls out his treasure. It's a Fashion Condom. Dad doesn't seem to know what it i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gave you THAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the room, "Nurse" Cooper winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did SHE get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derrick has a grin on his face. He shrugs. Dad blinks, puzzled. Thinking. Thinking. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacKay, a patient who has always looked curious, rea out to Dad... takes the condom from his hand to inspect i then passes it along to another patient... Dad is not sur he likes what they are doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolph the red nosed reindeer had a  little shiny nose and if you ever  saw him you would even say it glows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to play and sing... and the crowd is slow to j her, but the sing-a-long picks up as: ...the condom is passed around the circle of senile  inspectors, none quite sure what it is, as Dad's eyes fol the condom from hand to hand in the circle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they wouldn't let poor Rudolph  play in any reindeer games. Then one  foggy Christmas eve Santa came to  say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Similar scene with younger people. Gifts opened and tried out and worn. Don and Richie are on the periphery of the sing-along car around the piano. Don's gift is opened and in hand, it's  Natural Oatmeal Soap, nicely packaged. Richie is holding Barbie doll... negotiating a trade with a little girl for the Action Figure she has in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have six Barbies! And I LIKE Action  Man. I feel sorry for you and all  but... what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie shrugs. They move in closer... towards the piano  player, who sits with her little girl on the bench, playi and singing. She turns to Don. It's Jan Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in between notes) Hi, there. Mr. Markel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don gulps. Richie does a take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see Max. He's great. He  barks at everybody,... he's very  protective of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don smiles wanly. Richie is puzzled, thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! You got MY gift. See, it says  "from Jan."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don nods weakly. Richie is starting to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... I think I got YOURS! Yes?  Chanel... how nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up a tiny bottle of Chanel eau d'toilet. Don no uncomfortably as Richie gives him a sadly puzzled, dirty  look, and moves back and away into the crowd. Don doesn't know which way to go. Jan gets his attention to sing-a-lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three French Hens, Two turtle doves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and a Partridge in a Pear tree,  etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short Conga Line has started, those few able bodies hav joined in the Conga Line, singing, circling through the l room, singing. Dad and Sid included... and just as anothe chorus is sung, Nurse Cooper joins the group from down th hall... and she holds up her prize -- The birdcage with D two parakeets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...AND a Partridge in a Pear  Treeee...!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. She has scored a triumph with the crowd, and they continue to dance around and sing. Dad looks funny... and moves to Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His dolls. His dolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad reaches for the cage. She pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agitated, Dad takes a swipe at the cage. She pulls it awa taunting him. He takes another swipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His dolls!! His!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges and grabs the cage from her. Both Dad and the c crash to the floor. The birds fly out... Chaos reigns. The nurses come to Dad's aid. Nurse Cooper shouting her defense. The singing stops. The patients are frightened. The bird fly around through the people. Screa One of the birds lands on Mrs. Oakley... she shrieks and bird takes off. The nurses are chasing the birds. The bir are squawking. Sid takes Dad's hand -- and just as they are about to rea the door, Dad dashes over to the circle of patients, grab the condom as it's being passed by one gnarled hand to an gnarled hand... and he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... birds... come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid leads Dad through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one there as Sid leads Dad from the crowd seen in the  Living Room and into the hall. Sid looks around. No one t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy... crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the sanest thing you've ever  said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cloak room is there. Sid takes two overcoats, hands o to Dad... and two scarves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LET'S GO HAVE FUN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad grins nervously, but follows Sid to the front door... in the background, Derrick is on a chair coaxing one of t birds down from the chandelier. Two men with Santa Hats walk out the front door. Sid and  Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's snowing. Sid and Dad walk through the front gate and along the  neighborhood sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Where? We'll go to see the Man.  Want to find the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticket... see the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad smiles at Sid, bumps into a street lamp. Sid turns hi around and they go. It's a real Christmas night. Snow glistening on the groun neighborhood street lamps casting the long shadows of lea trees. One lone car is coming, it's headlights bright on the icy street. It's very slippery and the car moves at a snails  pace. It's actually a mini-pickup truck... The street lamp casts the long shadows of Two Men Walking then picking up a little speed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, remember... ...we were kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid just fast enough to get behind the pickup truck, secr grab on to its back gate, and planting his feet just righ Sid skates on the icy street. Dad loves it, and once Sid secured, Dad hurries to take a ride too. OUR VIEW rides with them as they ride with joyous smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Jingle Bells, Jingle Bells, Jingle  all the way...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...ingle -- boy-the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM THIS ANGLE, it's a quiet night on the thoroughfare, the street isn't icy, unlike the icy side street which  intersects it. Just now, coming gingerly towards us on th side street is the Mini-pickup truck, and when it gets to the intersection, it turns! Sent siding and sprawling int big embankment piled at the side of the road are it's  riders... Sid and Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SNOW BANK,
dialogues.text: Dad and Sid are sprawled with ecstatic and exhausted smil on their faces, catching their breath. Finally. Dad mumbles something and Sid agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. There's still life in the old  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is tracking something.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: It's a city bus coming up the thoroughfare. Dad jumps up. Starts running for the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go... go. Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad waves the bus down and the bus stops for him well bef the bus stop. The bus door opens, the Black DRIVER is in uniform except for a Santa Hat just like Dad's:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Brother Claus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therr -- stmash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are smart not to be drinking and  driving. Hop on board, Mr. Claus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad gets on halfway through the door... mumbles something excitedly, holds the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem... I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huffing as fast as his old legs will allow, Sid hustles u the street and onto a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver shuts the door and the bus goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad has gone to the back of the bus, but Sid, also in his Santa hat, tries to find some change in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ooops... looks like I'm an  embarrassed Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hell... it's Christmas. Don't  worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid pats his fellow Santa on the shoulder and moves to th back of the bus with Dad. Except from them, the bus is em They sit quietly next to each other. Dad grins devilishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad opens his clenched fist. Grins. In his palm is the Fa Condom. Sid smiles, grabs for it playfully; but Dad clinches his  fist. Holds it tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Christmas guests are just saying their goodbyes, kiss their loved ones, saying good-bye to the nurses and the  smiling Mrs. Oakley at the front door. Quickly, the regular patients are once again alone, makin way with their aluminum walkers amidst the after math of  wrapping paper, napkins, paper plates of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you will all agree...  it was a wonderful Christmas... and  now it's 7:30 and I'm sure you're  all tired, and I know those staff  members not on duty would like to  get home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old folks start moving back to their rooms, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
