dialogues.text: The City Bus moves up the street and pulls up to a bus st ON THE BUS' DOOR... ...as it opens and Sid gets out. Dad was behind him, but suddenly runs to the back of the bus. The bus driver shut the door and takes off. Sid watches as the bus moves up the street, then stops, t backs up all the way back to Sid.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR --
dialogues.text: -- as it opens and Dad is standing there. He just stands  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now. Merry Christmas. Make up  your mind... in or out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll get back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets in. So Dad gets out. Dad's outside and Sid is ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, is that it? What street do you  want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, roomie, get back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad stands in the snow, puzzled, looks around. Then he po down the side street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home? This is where you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad gets excited, points down the street!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I understand. You guys have  had one too many... but you have got  to make up your minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad had run and slipped and slided down the street... so shrugs and stumbles off the bus after him. The driver rolls his eyes, shuts the door, and drives off

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD
dialogues.text: As Sid runs towards him. Dad is standing next to someone' garbage cans. He picks up the garbage can covers from two cans, and has a gleam in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad barely waits for Sid as he throws one of the garbage covers on the ground and jumps on to it, leaves the other can cover behind as he starts sliding down the hilly subu street, picking up steam as he goes, looking back to Sid  with a crazy smile. Sid watches, calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't do that. It's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not heard. He picks up his garbage can cover, shrugs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, the nuts have taken over the  looney bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets on his can cover, and we watch him follow Dad dow the long hill of Christmas decorated fine homes. They are screaming into the cold silent night as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Oakley, dressed in her overcoat, the O.D. nurses, Mr Russel and Derrick and one or two onlooker patients are  standing in the room with two made and unfettered beds. The parakeets are back in their cage, and the cage is tap shut with silver plumbers tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go through this once  more. They were both seen when the  problem began.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Metropolis... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got so crazy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they are definitely not HERE...  so we'd better call the police again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shrug and look at each other collectively, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The view is like a picture postcard, decorated and lighte with flashing lights, a big Christmas tree in the living  room window. Otherwise the house is dark.

dialogues.speaker: ON SID AND DAD
dialogues.text: Standing, looking, their garbage can sleds just behind th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIS is where you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They trek up the steps...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRONT PORCH
dialogues.text: As they arrive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were rich. You got  the key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at the big front door, nods his head like a mys and reached up and over one of the porch lights, and...  viola... produces the key. Hands it to Sid, with a big gr Sid opens the door, and swings the door open. They walk in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a beautiful traditional home, replete with Craftsma 1930's furniture, Tiffany lamps, and... in the living roo the huge Christmas tree with dozens of already opened gif left under it and around the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what a nice family you've got.  Gifts everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around, Sid takes Dad's arm and leads him throu the foyer, and as they go, Sid stops Dad short. They are standing under a sprig of mistletoe. Sid looks at Dad, who is confused, and Sid gives him a bu on the cheek... Dad grins, and they continue in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best friggin' Christmas  of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING A WALL FULL OF SNAPSHOTS... not unlike the galler of snapshots on Dad's kitchen wall at his real home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding. Ding. Ding. (imitating Mrs.  Oakley's soprano) It's dinner hour. Dinner everyone.

dialogues.speaker: DAD AND SID ARRIVE INTO FRAME.
dialogues.text: Sid points out the gallery of snapshots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice family. That your wife? And  your son, nice lookin' man, and that's  your grandson. Nice. Here, you sit,  I'll get dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad sits as Sid moves to the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No picture of you, I see... just  like my family, I took all the  snapshots, so I'm never in any  pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes are focused on something.

dialogues.speaker: DAD'S VIEW
dialogues.text: One of the chairs at the kitchen table is on an angle. Da moves the chair to resemble the angle of MOM'S CHAIR at h real home. Sid moves to the table with an array of foods. The basic  food groups. Grapes, lettuce, two half gallons of ice cre two different flavors, and a big jar of pickles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I hate about Old Oaks.  You have to eat what they give you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid accidentally bumps Mom's Chair out of its position, s to sit. Dad quickly moves the chair back to its Mom's cha position. Sid blinks, decides not to sit there, and sits another chair, starts to serve the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we can find out just how come  pregnant women love to eat ice cream  and pickles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he serves ice cream and pickles onto Dad's plate. Dad starts to eat a pickle, dips it into the ice cream an eats it. He takes another long look at Mom's Chair, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Oakley with two police officers, and other officers  looking around the grounds in the b.g. with flashlights.  Three police cars are in the driveway, with flashing ligh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...now that I think of it, two of  our Christmas party visitors, Mr.  Sweeney, and Mr. Fiedler both reported  their overcoats missing... (referring to notes) ...one a long, brown gabardine, and  the other a tweedy grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police Officer takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible that they might not  have walked off... but were taken  home by their families...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, Mr. Graybar has no family,  and Mr. Markopolis... just got here...  ...maybe they went "home" to Mr.  Metropolis's house... Um, Nurse  Cooper, thank you, everything's under  control here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Cooper has stuck her nose out the front door. And s goes back in with a huff at Mrs. Oakley's insistence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're checking out Mr. Markopoulis's  house... but if they're not there,  we're going to have to put out a  news bulletin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, that would be negative  publicity for Old Oaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand... hopefully they'll  turn up in the next hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of mistletoe hangs over their heads. Mrs. Oakley  gives the officer a little peck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer smiles, tips his cap, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic is guiding two policemen through the house IN ONE FLU CAMERA SHOT. Vic talks nervously and the cops say nothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kitchen. Dining Room...  it's a Bert Norris built house...  1945, so you know it was well built  if you know Bert Norris' reputation...  but, hah, here I am trying to sell  you the house... when you're looking  to find out if... Mr. Markopoulis  tried to come home. You say he's  with Sid Graybar. I thought Sid  Graybar died... his daughter died  five years ago. I sold the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They inspected most of the house. Cop talks into a Cellul Walkie Talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in to phone) Officer Burton. We're at the house  on Dalton Street. No sign of them  here. Over (radio voice) Okay... we'll scout the bus station.  Over. Out. (to Vic) Thanks for your trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Christmas decorations are bright in the dark of the d until, within a few seconds, a big orange ball rises over the hill, and the dark turns to light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is asleep sitting up in his chair at the kitchen tabl One of the two gallons of ice cream has tipped over and i melted creamy contents are spilled on the table. The lett is wilted. The pickle jar is empty. A P.A. Amplified Voice fills the air with a Big Voice fro nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELLO. TESTING. TESTING. THIS IS THE  VOICE OF YOUR CONSCIENCE. YES, I  MEAN YOU. THIS IS THE VOICE... OF  'THE MAN.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes pop open. The VOICE continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The P.A.) THE VOICE OF THE MAN KNOWS ALL...  EVEN THOSE THINGS YOU NEVER TOLD  NOBODY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes pop open more. He looks around. Nobody. Sid's  gravelly old voice continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND EVEN THOUGH YOU ARE SENILE NOW  AND CONFUSED, YES, I, THE VOICE OF  THE MAN KNOWS THAT YOU CAN STILL  THINK AND REMEMBER AND FEEL THINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is really frightened. He starts to tremble and look t the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I didn't mean... who... you have  the ticket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid is by the Christmas tree, trying out one of the gifts Karaoke Sing-A-Long System, now being used like an amplif bullhorn. It bellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on bullhorn) YES... I HAVE THE TICKET. I KNOW  EVERYTHING. HAVE YOU BEEN GOOD OR  BAD IN YOUR LIFETIME?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's VOICE is heard from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...good! good! No... bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on bullhorn) THAT'S RIGHT. YOU'VE BEEN BAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE KITCHEN, Dad is unnerved. He thinks this is IT! Th end of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Please... good. Please. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad has been looking for The Voice, and he now starts to  walk into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOW GOOD? HAVE YOU EVER HUGGED YOUR  KIDS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad wanders into the room, listening to the voice, and ev though he sees Sid with the Sing-A-long toy, he doesn't g it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My woman... ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HMMM. THAT'S... BAD. Oops!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Dad standing right in front of him, puts down the sing-a-long bullhorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Who? Who? The man... the man  came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad nods. Nodding very low, then nodding very high. Noddi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah... what'd the man say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad points to himself, fingering his own chest several ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...good, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a GOOD man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad nods his head, yes, yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you must be a good man...  because... did you see how many  presents your family has given you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid gets up, takes Dad by the hand, and they go over to t tree, sit on the floor with all the gifts. There are the  gifts for the family, some for Mom, some for Dad, some fo boy about 12, and some for a girl about 8.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Sid and Dad play with the gifts. 1. They try on some clothes and hats. Sid puts a great, w sweater on Dad. Dad puts a fir hat on Sid's head. They st this way throughout. 2. Play with a radio controlled Ford Explorer SUV from ro to room. Dad runs the car from a battery operated remote his hand... and Sid runs after the car from room to room. Just as Sid reaches the car and starts to pick it up, Dad his the button and the car zooms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is packing a suitcase and talking on the phone at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) O.K., that's great... you'll buy the  non-taxable muni's -- pay seven and  a scrosh... you get the warrants  thrown in... and you let you IRA  sell Yahoo for the year end tax  loss... and you go into the new year  looking at a carryover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie walks by him again on the return, silently. Sit on the opposite side of the room, with his back turned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, John, Happy New Year... I'll  call tomorrow too. You, too. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FLUID CAMERA FOLLOWING
dialogues.text: Don hangs up, closes the suitcase, looks at his watch. wa into the kitchen, past Richie, without a word Don opens t refrigerator, bachelor empty, takes out a 7-Up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you packed? (no answer) Want a soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He shrugs, walks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Richie, this is an emergency...  I would really appreciate it if you'd  make it a little easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer from Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... I know it's not easy. So, if  you feel like you need to choose to  live with your Mom, I'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer from Richie. In fact, Richie's grim deadpan loo could kill. Don just looks out the window. On the street below, a cab just pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. The cab is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his suitcase and heads out the front door. He waits for Richie. Richie takes his time, picks up his  backpack and his hockey stick, and makes his way to the d passes his father within inches without a word. Don sighs and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Sid continue the silent but for MUSIC OVER MONTAG now they -- 3. Smash balls. Dad and Sid hit a soft rubber balls hard they can with wooden paddles, but it only floats through air, and they run to hit it... back and worth... back and forth just missing several disasters, and then like two  outfielders running for the same ball in the air, they sm into each other, and pratfall to the carpet, exhausted an happy. 4. Dad is dressing a Barbie doll, and loves it. Sid comes over with a big GI-Joe action figure and the two dolls st talking to each other in Barbie and GI Joe talk. 'Oh, hi Barbie.' 'Okay, I like your boobs.' Then, in fun, the two dolls start fighting, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a smaller interior, but again Don is crushed into hi seat, surrounded by larger people. Richie sits in an aisl seat three or four seats away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wished I hadn't lied to my son  about Max. I wished my Mom hadn't  died. I wished my Dad hadn't become  senile and nutty. I wished Richie  would decide to live with me, ...but  I felt relieved by that Judge... I  didn't have to make the decision. I  wished I was making more money. I  wished I lived on a farm or in Paris.  I wished I wasn't on an airplane  going back to Duluth again. I wished  I had a better life. And I wished  that wishing would make it so, because  even with all that wishing, I didn't  feel better about anything. So, ring  in the damn new year. Might as well.  Happy F-word New Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie is looking at him, also wishing something. Don fee his eyes... looks to Richie, smiles a little, and Richie  quickly averts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Dad and Sid continue their Montage sequence. 5. Sid picks up a video cassette, it's a home movie casse "To Jerry, from: Your 'LOVING' Wife." He puts it into the VCR. They sit, stare at the TV with jaws agape. ON TV: It's the wife (see snapshots in kitchen) and her  husband (see snapshots)... making love in their bedroom.  It's an amateur longshot, and as they have finished one p of love-making, they both laugh, turn to the camera, and  bow... and then applaud, then bow again, turn to each oth and resume the love-making. Dad and Sid applaud vigorously. 6. They open a fruitcake tin, unwrap the fruitcake and st to eat it in big chunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Vic are emerging from the Baggage Area. Don with one bag, and Richie tails behind with his attitude appare There's a homeless man with two children, who simply mumb "Spare change?" Vic reaches in and hands him some spare  change. Don doesn't really notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic, I feel like you're an old, old  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you'd forgotten, ol' buddy,  but I am an old, old friend. Don't  sweat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at Vic's car, a new Cadillac, throw Don's sui in the back seat, and Richie follows silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kid? You see a kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Vic. You're...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Richie, here only by accident  of birth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic shrugs and they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it's midnite... so not much  use doing anything about your Dad  tonite. So, we have plenty of room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Vic, we can stay at a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget. It's Duluth, the last  hotel they built was the Bates Motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car turns out of the airport onto the main thoroughfa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is one big mess. Gifts and clothing everywhere. Dad and Sid are sitting in big chairs. Sleeping sitting u each with fruitcake still in his hands. Dad with the Barb doll, also "sleeping", in the crook of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV IN KITCHEN
dialogues.text: A TV photo of Dad, followed by a photo of Sid Graybar,  segueing into a local news team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...both are local men, the two  retirees were discovered late last  night to have just walked out of the  annual Christmas Party at the Old  Oaks retirement home.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK REVEALS
dialogues.text: Don and Richie at the breakfast table with Vic and his fa It's a big unassuming kitchen for a big unassuming family Vic gets up and down to bring food to the table and to as his wife, Barb, capable and still pretty, and his three k 3, 8, and 13 are the good kind, helping and getting ready for school. TV remains on subliminally in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...your Dad is big news in Duluth.  Eat hardy, now... we got a big day  ahead of us... we gotta go find The  Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I need $1.50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the treasurer of the Art Club...  and we're short $1.50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic rolls his eyes, digs into his pocket, hands Vic, Jr. couple bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it's all about, Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad... nice meeting you  Richie... if you're still here on  Saturday, we have a hockey game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic, Jr. is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give him $1.50 now... maybe, if  I'm lucky he'll take care of me when  I get old and senile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get old and senile,  'cause I'm going to kill you with  kindness first. (she gives Vic a buss) More eggs, Don?... Richie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Barb... Richie, you want  more eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don pushes the eggs towards him. Richie burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, Mrs. Hudnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he does talk; just not to his  own father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don looks at Richie and Richie's look in return could bur through tempered steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police have checked the bus station  and the rescue shelters... and not a  sign of the two retirees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Stacey... there is one clue,  Dick Falsey interviewed a bus driver  Shawean McMillian...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV IN B.G.: There's the black Santa bus driver...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they were drunk... they  acted... um... weird... I never  thought they were that old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: CUT TO the corner of St. Clair and Mount Holyoke  Streets where the bus driver let them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this is the corner he left them  off at... at about 6:30 last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone has any information...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just call the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that gives US an idea where to  start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and, the two men are not thought  to be either armed or dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...depends on how you look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don laughs, looks to Richie to laugh with him, but Richie still won't talk to him or recognize that he's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid is standing at the window, peeking through the curtai In the background, WE HEAR a shower going, then stop. SID sees: HIS VIEW: A squad car passes slowly in the streets, stops some neighborhood kids who are sledding, asks them someth they shake their heads, and we overhear, we haven't seen  anyone... just people we know. The car goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, nothing lasts forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SID turns to Dad, now coming out of the bathroom... with pants on and trying to pull a woman's undies over his hea as he goes. In his mouth, he's carrying a brassier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid helps him to take the women's undies off his head, an helps him into his own shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very becoming, but you  wouldn't want me to get the wrong  idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the brassier from Dad, looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting bored, like me? Don't  you think we should get out of here  soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad agrees, nods yes, definitely, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you think we should get  caught... instead of just turning  ourselves in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad isn't sure, he shakes his head, no, then maybe, then  nods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pickles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad pulls something from his pocket. It's the fashion con Dad grins, tries like hell to wiggle his eyebrows like Gr Marx, on the make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's a good idea. Let's call  "Nurse" Cooper, have her come over,  have some fun... (Sid winks!) ...and then they can catch us, we'll  say gee whiz we're really sorry, but  we're too old to know any better.  Here, take us away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid puts his hands out to be "cuffed." Dad mimics the act Sid guffaws, and Dad guffaws with him, as Sid picks up th bedside phone, punches in the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, of course, we're going to clean  up your house... your family'll never  know we were even here. (phone answers "Old  Oaks") Hello... is Nadine Cooper there?  This is her nephew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse is at the desk holding the phone in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Miss Cooper, telephone. It's  your nephew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper hurries to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nephew... ? All the way from  England? (she takes the phone) Hello. Who...? Ohh. Ohhhhhhhh! Yes...  why... YES! Oh, I certainly could...  would... and... should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, looks around furtively, then heads back to room quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Sid are raiding the utility closet, pulling out a vacuum cleaner, a bucket and mop, a broom, duster, etc. S starts to fill the pail with water, and suds are starting form. He sees Dad, struggling with the plug to the vacuum clean he's trying to plug it into itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let me help with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid plugs it into the wall, and then Dad starts to vacuum with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooooo... this... is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad starts to vacuum in one direction... loves it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that way... this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the direction around, and Dad fights with him fo control of the vacuum, but Sid wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way... okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad agrees now and starts to vacuum in that direction, so Sid lets go and heads off, but see that -- Dad lets the vacuum cleaner go and watches it zoom off th the doorway into the dining room, and it's heading for... An huge antique art deco flower vase. Sid runs to catch it, and... just before it hits the Ming Vase... he does. He lifts the Deco vase as the vacuum goe by, and he cannot stop the vacuum in time... ON DAD -- delighted. ...when the vacuum drags a Tiffany standing lamp down and falls... slowly... teetering... Dad is watching it, his neck turning with every teeter. Sid now has the same problem, watching it teeter... and t finally, fall, and Sid runs... and... slides... ...just i time to catch the lamp by its shade on his chest, holds i in the air triumphantly, just like a center fielder. Dad laughs. Sid is just returning the lamp to its upright position, w he sees Dad's expression, puzzled. Sid turns to see what Dad sees, which is -- Foaming water pouring out of the utility room, under the  door, and into the hall, and down the stairs... foaming a flowing uncontrollably. Sid and Dad run to turn off the water, but of course they must run through the foam to get to its source, and they  slip and pratfall, get up, fall, slide a few feet, get up help each other, in fact hold on to each other as their l slip away and out from them in opposite directions. They stare into each others eyes, facing the inevitable,  kind of liking the experience IN SLOW MOTION, but finally ...slide and pratfall on their faces. They scream with  delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic's car is turning a corner as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, the real estate business is  like life. People. Family. People  taking risks, people making  commitments to other people, people  being with people, family... whatever.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR --
dialogues.text: Vic and Don in front seat, Richie, still with a chip, in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take a few risks, you sign 'em  up, hope for a sale... but when  there's a sale, Don, what a high!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, shame on you. It's the people...  with every sale there's a story...  not just ONE story, but two. The  seller's got a story, and the buyer's  got a story. It's the process of  living... right in front of my eyes,  somebody has a baby, needs more room,  somebody's mother-in-law moves in...  the neighborhood gets old... they  move... and I like the naked city,  there's a story... and I'm there,  part of the story... and when I can  help someone... that's a high!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don shrugs...it's hard for him to listen to Vic's patter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, even now... we're looking for  your Dad, who's... woooee... HE'S  "looking for the Man"... I know you  want to help him find the man... and  me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have passed through the neighborhood, and in fact th are this moment passing right by the Big house with the  decorations, and the kids sledding nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxicab pulls up outside and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two or three nurses are checking out for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...back after lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another nurse mumbles "back after Lunch," goes, and then third approaches the desk in a very large raincoat with t collar pulled up and a snow hat pulled down to her nose. can only see her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper heads for the front door, she can barely  believe it was so easy, too easy. Yep, too easy. As soon as she goes out behind the other two, the Check O Nurse is joined by Mrs. Oakley and they go to the window, pull the curtain back --

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE --
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper gets in the cab and the cab goes, and -- Mrs. Oakley and Check Out Nurse turn their heads --

dialogues.speaker: THEY SEE --
dialogues.text: Out of sight, Nurse Derrick and Nurse Russel get into the back of a Police Car and it pulls out... following the  taxicab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, soon enough... soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shares a nod with the Check Out Nurse, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic's car is driving on neighborhood streets... slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Vic and Don and Richie, eating McDonald's burgers, as  they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so when I met Barb... in the 7th  grade... you'd gone off to McKinley  Junior High... I stayed at Peabody...  and it was love at first sight...  and it was love at last sight too...  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is getting annoyed, either by Vic or the frustration one house after another but nothing to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see you still love her.  You have a great family, Vic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...there's no magic to it, just be  open. You could do it, Don. Find a  good woman, a REAL woman, make it  easier for your son to decide to  live with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, Vic... will you hang it up  for a minute! I tried. You did it.  You stayed home, I left for the big  city. Fame and fortune. You made it  on your terms, and I've made it...  on... mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic smiles, throws up his arms. In the back seat, Richie moves up to his father's ear in front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you listen to Vic? Why  don't you listen to anybody!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don turns his head, pretends to be cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, I'm talking to you, you  stupid prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don looks back at him. Richie strikes out at him with the hockey stick. Don grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine... you don't like me? Go live  with your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie jumps out of the back door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, I will. You prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone... slipping and sliding and the standing and ru away. Vic stops the car completely. Don jumps runs after Richie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie... come back here.

dialogues.speaker: ON RICHIE
dialogues.text: Running... running...running... it's hard to run on the  street, it's slippery, so he cuts in through a snow bank continues to huff through the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay away from me! You dumb  prick!

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: Running... running... running... it's hard to follow the  younger Richie and Don's starting to huff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie...!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie runs some more. Huffing, looking back after his fa catching up, calling to him. Richie still had his hockey  stick in hand, and... whoops, he trips on the stick, stum and falls, starts to get back up, but -- Don jumps over h holding him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go of me! I hate you! I hate  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie tries to hit him with the hockey stick, but Don gr it, and pushes it against Richie's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you hate me, I must be doing  a good job. Boys are supposed to  hate their fathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This enrages Richie, who can't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real fathers don't lie! You lied to  me... you lied to me! Fathers don't  lie... that's why you're a prick!

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: His expression is wide-eyed and he's out of control, trem he makes a fist, cocks his arm back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, you prick! Hit your own  son, beat me up... just like YOUR  father beat you, you prick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don smashes his fist... but -- Someone's hand catches his arm. Holds it. Holds it. Tremb Trembling. Don looks up. It's Vic, holding his arm, challenging him eye to eye, ar to arm. Don looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the Hell ARE you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your best friend. Check -- I'm  your only friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic still holds Don's wrist. Still trembling, Don takes a deep breath, tries to catch his breath... Vic finally lets go, and Don let's his trembling arm down Don, his whole body trembling now, looks at Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie... forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie doesn't forgive him, not yet. Richie pulls himself out from under his father, and gets up, picks up his hock stick and starts trekking back to the car. Vic holds his hand out to Don, helps him up. Don brushes  himself off, starts to follow Richie. Vic puts his arm ov Don's shoulder as they go. Don just barely allows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever had a shock run through  your whole body. Like an electric  current. Like the Electric Chair.  That's what happened to me. Sometimes  it takes some shock, some wild moment  in your life -- someone's death, or  maybe you come near dying yourself  somehow. Something to change your  life, something to shake you up from  the inside out... and you never really  know when or where it's going to  come from. In my case, it was my  son... and my... my... best friend,  Vic Hudnut, who did it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach Vic's car in LONG SHOT; get back into Vic's ca silently, and Vic drives off down the streets again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper is putting on lipstick, and unbuttoning th top buttons of her blouse, pulling down the lapels to rev some substantial cleavage, albeit wrinkled. The cabdriver turns up the main thoroughfare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon? How soon? Juniper Street...  3-3-2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streets are slippery, ma'am. We're  getting there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks into his rearview mirror, and sees what he expec to see. The police car behind him has turned at the same  corner he turned at. He takes a breath. Nurse thinks for a second, makes a decision, and unbutton even one more button, looks ahead confidently.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD --
dialogues.text: Peeking through the living room window. He gets excited.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW --
dialogues.text: Vic's car is pulling up in front of the Big House, and Vi and Don and Richie are getting out. Dad runs to Sid, jumping up and down like a dog who needs go out to pee, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tickets. The Ticket, She needs...  too many. BLISTER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son? Here...? Now? What about  Nurse Cooper...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid runs to the window, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW THROUGH CURTAINS
dialogues.text: Don and Richie and Vic walking up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy. Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, Richie, Vic walking up to the house, stopping to loo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...hard to say... I don't know why I  didn't think of it... the Hansen's  went to Florida Christmas Day...  it's worth a try...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up further...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grampa!

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: Dad in the window, holding the curtains back, frozen ther

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is frozen at the curtain, but Sid comes into view, lo through the window, sees them coming and pulls Dad away f the curtains. Don and Vic look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we break in, we're trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the doorbell, Don rings it. Richie looks throu the side windows. HE SEES: Sid pushes Dad down the hall away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're running away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic and I'll go around back. Richie...  stay here in case they come out the  front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They split up as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nurse" Cooper on the edge of the back seat, as the drive turns... and yes it's down Juniper Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Lady... just down the street  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may say it, lady, for your age...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, for my age...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you're the sexiest fox I've ever  seen. There's the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... what an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Cooper is excited. Suddenly, her eyes widen, then pop.

dialogues.speaker: HER VIEW THROUGH ADVANCING WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: FULL VIEW -- the house, with Richie out front and on the  roof... two men climbing on to the roof from an attic's p window... then working their way around the roof to the  backside of the roof's peak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do YOU see what I see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the cab, the Police Car turns on its SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: looking down the street, the cab and the police car with sirens. He wonders what's happening, then looks up to see Dad and Sid just disappearing around to the backside of the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad holds his nose like he's jumping into a pool, and the slide down the snowy slope of the roof...

dialogues.speaker: ON DON VIC AND RICHIE
dialogues.text: ...running around to the back of the house. Don leads the way now, possessed, fearless, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAD! Where'd they go? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD AND SID
dialogues.text: ...landing in a pile of snow, Dad helps Sid getup and the start to run through the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON, VIC AND RICHIE
dialogues.text: ...running around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK YARD
dialogues.text: As Don, Richie and Vic arrive where Dad and Sid just were They turn this way and that, trying to figure it out. Ric points at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footprints!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don leads the way, as they all start following the footpr like bloodhounds, methodically... and all too slowly... a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the three footprint detectives in the background, th don't see what we see -- THE DOOR OF THE GARAGE OPENS AUTOMATICALLY, revealing Sid just behind the door, and suddenly one of the cars in the garage, The Jeep Cherokee-4WD revs its engine, starts bac out without stopping and then the Jeep blasts out in reve

dialogues.speaker: ON DON, RICHIE AND VIC
dialogues.text: Their heads turn, and their eyes... POP!

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: Amazed, terrified...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAD! DON'T...!! DAD, STOP!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don runs -- trudging through the snow... to get to the  driveway, too late to do anything, but just in time to wa

dialogues.speaker: DON'S VIEW
dialogues.text: As the Jeep zooms out in reverse... and instead of stoppi or turning into the street, the Jeep runs across the stre and up the lawn of the house across the street, finally  stopping when it hits the trunk of the big oak tree, but digging a rut from the wheels reving against the force of the tree. Don runs after -- as Vic and Richie struggle to keep pace well behind.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: The cab has stopped on the street, and the cop car has  stopped. The cops have gotten out of the car and are star to walk up to the house, when the Jeep slips and slides  quickly up the lawn across the street.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE JEEP
dialogues.text: Dad and Sid, with Dad at the wheel, trying to shift into  another gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUR! See... more! Fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Do it! I told you. I don't  drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Sid finally helps him, shift into first gear. Dad  steps on the gas... they go. The blind leading the blind.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: As the Jeep swings out, slides, and finally goes down the street, nearly missing a few parked cars, and the kids wh were sledding disperse fast. The two cops jump into the squad car and take off, slippi and finally sliding 180 degree turnaround to follow the J

dialogues.speaker: ON DON,
dialogues.text: arriving at Vic's car -- he jumps in, starts it, revs it, burns rubber on the ice, slides around 180 degrees, just time to pick up Vic and Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm driving, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They jump in as the car moves off, slipping and sledding.

dialogues.speaker: ON NURSE COOPER
dialogues.text: Stepping out of the cab with one hand on the door, Watchi the events unfold, looking this way, then that way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing... amazing... (she jumps back in  the cab) Follow that car. AND that one! And  that one too!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxicab takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three cars, two of them following the Jeep, which is basi frenetic in the directions it chooses to go. It goes up  Juniper Street, then turns into and through someone's  driveway, through the backyard, and right through a row o bushes, and into the opposing house's back yard, then,  reversing angle, through and out their driveway onto the  next street, and Vic's car goes right through and the pol car follows and goes right through too, but not the taxic which despite Nurse Cooper's directions goes around the b but comes out just in time to be actually ahead of the Je as the Jeep emerges, and the Jeep slams into the back of taxicab and starts pushing it down the street, with the c driver yelling to stop, and Nurse Cooper having the time her life, waving to the drivers of the Jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's Nurse Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad smiles, and they wave to Nurse Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: As a fifth vehicle, the WDDD-TV "EYE WITNESS NEWSVAN" joi the parade. The side door is open, and a videocam man hangs precariou out the door, shooting the scene -- while another man hol tight on to his shoulder harness.

dialogues.speaker: IN VIC'S CAR
dialogues.text: Don is driving Vic's new Cadillac like a race driver, a w knuckler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's turning into the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEIR VIEW -- as the Jeep turns into a rocky, hilly park. The Jeep goes over one hill, and another -- and finally h a ditch, starts to rev its wheels and can't move out.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: As Don's car runs over the same embankment and falls into the same ditch, spins its wheels but it's no-go. And after that, the police car runs into the same ditch,  spins its wheels and it's no-go. The taxicab follows. Same deal. The newsvan follows and dips into the same ditch. Same re The cameraman jumps out of the van with a Mini-Cam on his shoulder to stay on scene, and a NEWSCASTER, STACEY, jump into the snow with a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the residents, elderly and nurses are glued to th TV News event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Jim, the two retirees, may now be  trapped... in a ditch... and, let's  just hope they can be rescued without  incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo! Boo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Oaks residents, even the nurses, are on the edge their seats.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV SET
dialogues.text: While the Jeep spins its wheels, the police, Nurse Cooper and the Newscaster with the Mic are seen trudging through the snow... from the ditch where their vehicles got stuck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is accelerating wildly. Sid looks at the gear box. Sees: CLOSE: GEARBOX LEVERS, One level reads: "4WD" Sid pushes the lever and --

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: The Jeep's wheels grab the ground and it grumbles out of ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The residents cheer wildly.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: Don and Richie and Vic watch the Jeep go over a ridge and they groan -- Don hits the wheel with the palms of his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He revs it hard, again and again, but it's no go.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: The cops and the newsmen and Nurse Cooper... each forty f from the other, and groaning and turning nearly in unison and trudging through the snow in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough and tumble, slip and slide... Dad and Sid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...turn it that way. That way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do my own...! ...find the man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man you wanna find and The Man I  wanna find are two different guys.  You are gonna get us killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at him with a Who-Cares grin... and turns it th other way. They start to struggle for control of the whee ON DON IN VIC'S CAR Reving it, again and again. Turning t wheel, and then... suddenly the wheels catch a tree's roo and --

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CAR
dialogues.text: As it shoots out of the ditch, and they spin out and away

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JEEP
dialogues.text: Slipping and sliding and rolling over a ridge, nearly tip over, then righting itself, and going strong --

dialogues.speaker: ON SID
dialogues.text: -- his eyes popping at his view ahead. He holds on for de life. HIS VIEW THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD -- They are heading for a cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading for disaster... as the Jeep sails right up and ov the cliff --

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CLEAR BLUE SKY AS
dialogues.text: The Jeep sails effortlessly through the blue.

dialogues.speaker: ON FACES
dialogues.text: As Don drives towards the cliff... craning necks to follo then quickly chins drop and eyes turn down as --

dialogues.speaker: ON JEEP
dialogues.text: In the blue sky in faltering slomo, then it plummets to e and plows head first into a snow bank in the gulley below

dialogues.speaker: ON VIC'S CADILLAC
dialogues.text: flying through the snow towards the cliff, and just in ti

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: turns the wheel hard, and --

dialogues.speaker: THE CADILLAC
dialogues.text: turns, slides around and around, and then stops... right the edge of the cliff... miraculously. Don jumps out and  runs to the edge of the cliff. Richie and Vic follow.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR VIEW FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: The Jeep is buried head first in the snowbank, it's door  flung open, and on one side Dad's lifeless body is strewn the snow next to the Jeep.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: Terror on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAD!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don leaps off the cliff without a second of hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAD!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie runs to the cliff side. Looks down, as does everyo they've all finally caught up.

dialogues.speaker: WITH VIEW ABOVE GULCH
dialogues.text: Don has fallen in the snow face first, motionless for a s second, GASPS HEARD from above, then he moves, looks to D body... and rolls over to it. He looks into Dad's dead fa starts to weep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? -- Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Dad opens his eyes, looks at Don... grins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws snow in Don's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad -- my God. You scared the crap  out of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Don throws some snow back in Dad's face. They both gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie... he's okay.

dialogues.speaker: ON RICHIE AT THE TOP OF THE CLIFF
dialogues.text: looking down, tears in his eyes. And before Vic can stop  him, Richie leaps... over the edge of the cliff.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE BELOW
dialogues.text: As Richie falls on the other side of his father, and he t snow in Dad's face too. The three of them in a snow fight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticket... you got the ticket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with tears of joy) Yes, Dad... yeah, I got the ticket.  And I found The Man, too. I did,  Dad. I found the goddamn Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, trying to throw snow, but he can't. He's laughing (o is that crying) so hard he can't move. Richie puts his ar around him, and Dad, laughing hysterically, jumps on them both...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The residents watching TV... cheer!

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE OTHERS AT THE TOP OF THE CLIFF
dialogues.text: Nurse Cooper wiping a tear from her eye. Vic nods and nods and nods as his joyous grin widens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motionless. Then, he falls over... dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the drama's participants start to disperse... the VIEW PULLS BACK AND BACK AND BACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I think, had finally found the  man. And I knew that I had found the  man too... I still didn't know exactly  what it meant, but I understood that  Dad knew what it meant, and it was  better not to try to describe it...  you know... describe it... he just  KNEW. And now, I just KNEW. And I  think, maybe, Richie just KNEW too...  and, goddamn, what a wonderful thing  it is to find The Man. You know, the  one inside yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As OUR VIEW PULLS BACK, the entire city of Duluth is reve below... and the heavy drone of a Jetliner becomes  overwhelming, mixing with the sound of DON'S VOICE, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is looking through the window at the scene below... t City of Duluth receding into the distance, and PULLING BA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally got a window seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...his place at the window now REVEALED, AND PULLING BACK MORE, DAD is sitting next to him, fast asleep, and the ai just across from Dad, Richie is playing a video game with Don's laptop computer, looking over to check on Grampa ev once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't going to be easy. They say  that the things that are worthwhile  in life are never easy... you have  to work at it... at least you do in  this day and age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad opens one eye, then the other, looks over at the dozi Don, then the other way, sees Richie, winks, then looks a Don again and grins. Reaches out for Don's hand. Don blin awake as Dad slams his palm against Don's palm, then take his hand away, like a magician... and leaving an object i Don's palm. It's the Fashion Condom. Don looks in his palm, and grins. Dad grins knowingly. Ri looks at it, turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy. Busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get up. Struggles with his seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Dad! You can't get up. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... Grampa needs to go to the  bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie helps Dad out of his seat belt, and they head up t aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I learned anything about My Dad  as an Old Timer's patient it was  that more often than not, there was  a method to his madness... so I have  a hunch he knew how important he is,  how important it was for him to serve  as the missing link...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lavatory door, reading "Occupied", and a line of peop waiting outside. Richie looks at his watch, and smiles  sheepishly at the next person in line. Richie knocks on the door. A Stewardess now comes forward and knocks on the door with a crowbar. And just as she's  about to force the door open, the "Occupied" sign turns t "Vacant" and Dad emerges with shaving cream all over his  face and head and hands, and no razor to be seen. He didn need a shave anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not just the missing link between  my old home and my new home, but  between the generations... the link  to my own son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie leads Dad back to his seat, helps him sit down, an then straps his seat belt for him. Don and Richie exchang little knowing grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe Richie felt that too.  He understood how important my Dad  was to him, too.

dialogues.speaker: ON DON
dialogues.text: Don shuts his eyes and takes a deep breath. Sunlight stre in through the window over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Richie and Don riding a walking sidewalk. Dad fee funny about it, so he sort of dances to keep his feet off the ground as much as he can. Richie is holding an airline carton marked "Fragile, Livi Animals", with little holes and the sound of Parakeets  chirping inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Richie and Don emerge with their baggage. Formerl Santa Claus, now the same guy has a sign, "Homeless... wi work for food" guy is outside the door, and this time, Do gives him some money, returns the homeless man's nod. Dad starts to cross the street, and they catch him just a he's about to be hit by a Tram from the Portland Sheraton Hotel. And as the tram passes, an old pickup truck is revealed  pulling up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was New Year's Eve day, and...  surprise... I had made a New Year's  date... with, guess who, Jan Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan leans over Bren to open the shotgun door and waves. D doesn't see her, not until Max, the dog, barks from the b of the truck... and Don waves back, moves with Dad and Ri to the truck. The truck also has some young potted evergr trees in the truck bed. Max is barking and shaking and jumping with joy at seeing Dad, and Dad feels the same way, and just climbs in the  truckbed with him, and Richie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We left Bren and Richie to baby-sit  Dad and the birds and Max, who was  so happy when he saw Dad that he  just went nuts. Dogs know. Dogs  experience what every human wants to  experience, unconditional love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck pulls out into traffic, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "JAN PATRICK NURSERY - We have anything you need."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the truck pulls up in front, and Jan lets everyone off except for Don. Then it drives off again. ON DON AND JAN.

dialogues.speaker: ON A MOUNTAIN CREST
dialogues.text: She smiles and he smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it, we never said  one word to each other that whole  magical New Year's Eve night. Jan  and I were experiencing something...  unconditional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Jan in the truckbed having dinner, wrapped in a b Hudson Bay blanket. Mount Hood is in the distance as the sets behind it. They toast each other, clinking champagne glasses. Don's  Voice never has sounded so mellow, easy, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drank champagne, waited patiently  'till midnite, drank more champagne.

dialogues.speaker: TIME PASSING --
dialogues.text: Don and Jan sitting up, wrapped together cozily in the  blanket, until the SOUND OF SOME NEW YEAR'S REVELERS' yel Happy New Year from a passing car.

dialogues.speaker: TIME PASSING AGAIN --
dialogues.text: Jan and Don come together and exchange their first kiss, they like it so much that they do it again... and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we kissed and kissed and kissed  and then we screwed our brains out.  Nobody makes love on the first date  anymore, but it just seemed right...  not only did we practice safe sex...  but we used the fashion condom Nurse  Cooper had given Dad, and he had  given me. That seemed just right.  Then we slept in the back of the  truck 'till dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR VIEW has delicately MOVED AWAY to the STARLIT NIGHT a then, as the Sun Rises over Mount Hood, OUR VIEW returns the sleepers, molded together, under the blankets in the  open truckbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful sunny day... mountains in the distance... bir chirping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have been doing something  right... All my New Year's wishes  came true. Jan and I were married. I  sold my condo, and that paid off the  mortgage on Jan's little farm. We  grew things... and made a living at  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don loads some little seedlings onto the back of the truc Richie's mother called me that very day, New Year's, and  told me she'd gotten married in Hawaii...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Cleaning up the kitchen table, a gallery of family photos the wall behind her. Many of the photos are from the old  gallery wall in the kitchen at Dad's house. But, just as  many or more are new, and many of them have Don in the  snapshots, with Jan, with Richie, playing with Max, with  Dad, with Bren. And, finally, a big one of Sid, in front the Christmas tree at the big house, smiling in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it, she said, really unfair  to put so much pressure on Richie to  decide which parent he should live  with... and wasn't it time that a  son Richie's age lived with his father  and visited his mother once in a  while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan moves to the kitchen window, her back to us, revealin in the FOREGROUND that the kitchen table she was wiping i the dinette set from Dad's house, and, yes, MOM'S CHAIR i set at the old Mom's Chair angle. Jan watching through the window as --

dialogues.speaker: HER VIEW THROUGH THE WINDOW --
dialogues.text: Richie comes along to help... and approaches Bren, then p a squirt gun out from behind his back and squirts her... pushes him, then runs... and he chases her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what's her name -- Dorothy in  the Wizard of Oz, I'd learned so  much from the most surprising  places... from My Dad, who couldn't  think straight, from my son, who I  thought was supposed to learn about  life from me, and from Vic Hudnut in  my hometown, the best friend I didn't  even know I had... 'til he saved my  life... and from Jan, who came from  Heaven to share her love with mine.

dialogues.speaker: STILL ON JAN LOOKING OUT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: -- as Don catches her glance and throws her a kiss. Jan g sighs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turned out Jan was not a divorced  woman... she was a widow. Her husband  caught a cold one day and just up  and died of Pneumonia. Shit happens.  Life is a bitch, and then you die. I  don't like that saying. Uh-uh. Life  is precious, live it! That's what I  say, that's what My Dad does every  day.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAD
dialogues.text: Dad is throwing bird seed to the winds, and a hundred bir fly in and out of nowhere and start pecking at the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, well, you know My Dad, the  missing link... the man with a method  to his madness. He'd found the man  just like I had -- but it takes a  woman too. So, Jan and I figured Dad  ought to have a full time, around  the clock nurse...

dialogues.speaker: REVEALING --
dialogues.text: Nurse Cooper breezes into frame, dressed like a real nurs frilled head crown and all, -- joins Dad, crushing her am bosom into his ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost time for our nap, Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes widen, as her hand moves down to his butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it just seemed our family was  destined to grow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The homeless guy from Portland Airport comes out of a she with a bushel of tomatoes, asks where he should put them, and Don points to the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and grow... again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan walks into frame, her belly heavy with child. She sta with Don and squints as they look to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times have changed, it's harder to  find the man, and all this love stuff  must sound really corny now, but,  you know what, I'll put all my money  on corn any day of the week. There's  still a good life out there, you can  still look life right in the face,  and demand that good life and grab  it while there's still time. If you  haven't found the man yet, I know  you can, and I know you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING OVER DON AND JAN'S SHOULDERS TO THE HORIZON, the  beautiful mountains, blue sky, and white clouds. MUSIC, OUR THEME IS UP, AND AWAY.
